LETTER TO THE EDITOR
The performance of the multimodal large language model GPT‑4 
on the European board of radiology examination sample test
Muhammed Said Beşler1 
Received: 19 March 2024 / Accepted: 24 March 2024 / Published online: 3 April 2024 
© The Author(s) under exclusive licence to Japan Radiological Society 2024
I read with great interest the study conducted by Nakaura 
et al., which investigates the potential of Generative Pre-
trained Transformers (GPT) in generating radiology reports 
[1]. I aimed to explore the capacity of the multimodal large 
language model (LLM) in addressing multiple-choice and 
image-based radiology exam questions.
Large language models are advancing in radiology for 
tasks such as report generation, clinical decision support, 
and data analysis [2 ]. ChatGPT has achieved satisfactory 
results in radiology board exam questions that do not include 
images [3, 4]. The latest version, GPT-4, a multimodal LLM, 
is capable of providing text output not only from text input 
but also from image inputs. A sample test consisting of 
seven multiple response questions from the European Board 
of Radiology (EBR) exam organized by the European Soci-
ety of Radiology was reviewed (https:// edir. myebr. org/ pub-
lic/ sampl e/? id= 52# exam/ 52). Data collection from GPT-4 
was conducted in March 2024. The questions indicate that 
multiple answers could be correct, and one question requires 
the correct sequencing of anatomical locations. While the 
maximum score per question is 1, incorrect answers result in 
point deductions (https:// www. myebr. org/ edir- scori ng- faqs#: 
~: text= Pass% 20mar k(WWS)% 20% 3D% 20Min imum,% 
25)% 20and% 20Max imum(70% 25)). GPT-4 achieved a 50% 
accuracy by scoring 1.5 out of 3 in purely text-based ques-
tions. In questions including images, it reached 1.67 points, 
achieving 41.75% accuracy. Overall, it secured 3.7 out of 7 
points, attaining a performance of 45.3%.
The performance of GPT-4 in multiple-choice questions 
that require medical image analysis and may have multi-
ple correct answers is noteworthy. The performance in a 
complete EBR exam, which includes free text responses, is 
of interest. The broad potential of multimodal LLMs from 
radiology reporting to clinical support tools will inspire new 
studies.
